questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease.

 

 

The 'silent choroid' or 'dark choroid' phenomenon is caused by the obscuration of the background choroidal fluorescence due to diffuse abnormalities in the retinal epithelium (RE). The accumulation of lipofuscin within the RE is a hallmark feature of Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM), which is the most prevalent type of macular dystrophy.

 

Signs:

 

  • The macula may initially be normal, later progressing to an oval 'snail slime' or 'beaten bronze appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions are seen at the level of the RPE.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence. Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). shows hypofluorescent spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best's disease: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin-like material within the RPE but does not typically feature a silent choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with drusen and neovascular changes rather than a silent choroid.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling of the macular region of the retina due to fluid accumulation in the cystoid spaces, not linked with the silent choroid phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass filling posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The above clinical scenario with recurrent spontaneous bleeding with unilateral nasal obstruction and contrast-enhanced CT showing a growth protruding into the nasopharynx, along with the Transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Epistaxis
  • Progressive nasal obstruction
  • Denasal speech
  • CHL
  • Broadening of nasal bridge
  • Proptosis leading to frog-face deformity
  • Involvement of cranial nerves – II, III, IV and VI

 

IOC is CECT – anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Millar sign)

 

Biopsy is avoided.

 

Treatment of choice – surgical approach

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antrochoanal Polyp: Typically arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, generally not as aggressive or vascular.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: A chronic granulomatous condition caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the nasal passages and respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Concha Bullosa: An aerated turbinate that usually does not present with bleeding or significant obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Prompt and accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is critical due to its potential for significant bleeding and local invasiveness. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, with preoperative planning crucial to manage the vascular nature of the tumor effectively.

choices.text: Simple Face Mask

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is brought to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, cough, and hypoxia. On examination, his oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. The medical team decides to initiate oxygen therapy to improve his oxygenation status. Based on the patient's current presentation, the goal is to provide the highest concentration of oxygen available using conventional oxygen delivery methods. Which device would be the most appropriate to achieve this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-rebreather Mask

 

Explanation:

 

The non-rebreather mask is the best choice for delivering the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy. This mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. The mask includes a reservoir bag filled with oxygen and one-way valves that prevent the patient from inhaling exhaled air. This design allows the patient to breathe almost pure oxygen, which is especially useful in emergencies requiring rapid improvement of oxygenation.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A) Simple Face Mask: This mask delivers a lower FiO2 of around 60% at 10 L/min, making it insufficient for patients needing higher oxygen concentrations.

 

Option B) Nasal Cannula: A nasal cannula provides an FiO2 of up to 44% at 6 L/min, suitable for mild hypoxia but inadequate for severe respiratory distress.

 

Option D) Venturi Mask: The Venturi mask delivers an adjustable FiO2 between 24-66% depending on the flow rate and entrainment device used, offering precise oxygen delivery but not the highest concentration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The non-rebreather mask delivers the highest FiO2 among conventional oxygen therapy devices, up to 80% at 10-15 L/min, making it ideal for situations requiring rapid oxygenation improvement in patients with severe hypoxia.

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:  Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.

 

Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S3

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to accommodate the increased blood volume and cardiac output required to support both the mother and the developing fetus. One of the normal physiological changes includes the presence of the S3 heart sound.

 

  • S3 Heart Sound: The S3 sound, also known as the ventricular gallop, is due to rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles. It is commonly heard in pregnant women due to the increased blood volume and cardiac output.

 

Other heart sounds mentioned are not typically considered normal in pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. S4 Heart Sound: The S4 sound, or atrial gallop, is generally associated with pathological conditions such as left ventricular hypertrophy or myocardial ischemia. It is rare in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Fixed Splitting of S2: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is usually indicative of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and is not normal in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Pericardial Knock: This is a sound heard in cases of constrictive pericarditis and is not a normal finding in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S3 heart sound is considered normal during pregnancy due to the increased blood volume and rapid diastolic filling of the ventricles.

 

Ref: Page no 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Severe illness which is  constant threat to life

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe illness

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Mild illness: This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.

 

Option B. Moderate illness: This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).

 

Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.

 

The classification system is as follows:

 

  1. ASA I: A normal healthy patient.
  2. ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease.
  3. ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  4. ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  5. ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  6. ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High flow nasal cannula

 

  • Components:
    • Flow generator: This delivers a continuous flow of medical gas, which can be up to 60 liters per minute (L/min) or more in some devices.
    • Heated humidifier: The gas is passed through a humidifier, which warms and saturates the gas with water vapor, providing near 100% humidity. This prevents mucosal drying and enhances mucociliary clearance.
    • Nasal cannula: Despite the term "nasal cannula," the prongs for HFNC are broader and shorter than traditional cannulas. They don't completely occlude the nares, allowing for the patient to breathe room air in addition to the provided gas mixture if needed.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Gas Conditioning: The humidified and warmed gas ensures better comfort and reduced airway resistance, potentially improving mucociliary function.
  • PEEP Effect: The high flow rates create a degree of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the nasopharynx. This can be beneficial in preventing alveolar collapse and can recruit alveoli, improving oxygenation.
  • Enhanced CO2 Washout: HFNC reduces the anatomical dead space in the nasopharynx, aiding in more efficient removal of carbon dioxide.
  • Continuous High Flow: The high flow rates ensure that the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is more consistent, irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern.

 

Advantages:

 

  • Better oxygenation: By delivering higher flow rates, HFNC can achieve better and more consistent oxygenation compared to standard oxygen therapy.
  • Comfort: Patients often find HFNC more comfortable than non-invasive positive pressure ventilation masks.
  • Flexibility: Patients can eat, drink, and communicate while using HFNC.

 

Indications:

 

  • Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure: Especially if caused by conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
  • Post-extubation support: In patients at risk for reintubation.
  • During procedures: Like bronchoscopy, to maintain oxygenation.
  • In conditions like COPD and asthma: It may aid in CO2 washout.

 

Limitations and Contraindications:

 

  • Severe hypercapnic respiratory failure: HFNC doesn't provide as much ventilation support as bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) or mechanical ventilation.
  • Uncooperative or unconscious patients: Due to aspiration risk.
  • Facial trauma or recent facial surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical ventilator: A mechanical ventilator is a device used to support or replace spontaneous breathing. It is more complex and provides controlled ventilation through an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Infusion pump: An infusion pump delivers fluids, such as nutrients and medications, into a patient's body in controlled amounts. It is not related to respiratory support.

 

Option C. CPAP machine: A Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) machine delivers a continuous level of positive airway pressure to keep the airways open. It is commonly used in sleep apnea but does not provide the high flow rates and humidification characteristic of HFNC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

  • Propofol is notorious for causing pain upon injection.
  • The pain can be severe and is often described as a burning sensation.
  • Various techniques and adjuncts, like mixing with lidocaine or injecting into larger veins, have been recommended to minimize the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While ketamine can sometimes cause a burning sensation upon injection, it's not typically described as the most painful among anesthetic agents. However, when not combined with other medications, it can cause some discomfort upon injection.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate can cause pain on injection, but the pain is generally less severe compared to propofol.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause some pain upon injection, but it's generally less painful than propofol. However, it can cause tissue necrosis if it is inadvertently injected outside of the vein (extravasation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:


The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.

 

Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.

 

Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.

 

Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.

 

Educational Objective:


The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.

 

Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. The clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor. Which of the following is the most appropriate test in this scenario? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal fibronectin

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) is a glycoprotein produced by fetal amnion cells and found in high concentrations in amniotic fluid. It is also found in cervico-vaginal secretions in early pregnancy (less than 22 weeks) and late pregnancy (greater than 37 weeks). The presence of fFN in cervico-vaginal secretions between 22 and 37 weeks is used as a predictor of preterm labor.

 

A fFN level greater than 50 ng/mL is considered a significant predictor of preterm labor. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) does not recommend routine use of fFN testing but it can be helpful in specific clinical scenarios where preterm labor is suspected.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Alpha fetoprotein: Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) is used in prenatal screening for neural tube defects and as a component of the quadruple marker test for Down syndrome. Elevated AFP levels are associated with neural tube defects, while decreased levels can indicate Down syndrome.

 

Option B. Beta HCG: Beta HCG is used in early pregnancy for confirming pregnancy and in first trimester screening for Down syndrome (where levels are elevated). It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.

 

Option D. PAPP-A: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is used in first trimester screening for Down syndrome, where its levels are decreased. It is not used for diagnosing preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal fibronectin (fFN) testing is the most appropriate test for assessing the risk of preterm labor in a woman presenting with lower abdominal pain at 31 weeks of gestation. A positive fFN test (greater than 50 ng/mL) can help predict the likelihood of preterm labor.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 366

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing emergency surgery due to acute appendicitis. During intubation, the anesthesiologist uses an endotracheal tube to secure the airway. After successful intubation, the anesthesiologist explains the features of the tube, including one that provides an additional pathway for air in case of obstruction. Which feature of the endotracheal tube provides this safety mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Murphy’s Eye

 

Explanation:

 

Murphy’s eye is a key safety feature found on endotracheal tubes, located near the distal end of the tube, opposite the main lumen. This side hole serves as an alternative pathway for air to flow in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed by secretions, blood, or pressure against the tracheal wall. By maintaining an airway in such situations, Murphy’s eye helps ensure continued ventilation and reduces the risk of respiratory compromise. Additionally, it minimizes the risk of tracheal mucosa injury by reducing suction effects when the main tip of the tube is occluded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cuff: The cuff is an inflatable balloon at the distal end of the endotracheal tube that seals the airway to prevent air leakage and aspiration of secretions. While it plays a critical role in maintaining a secure airway, it does not provide an alternate pathway for ventilation like Murphy’s eye.

 

Option C. Pilot balloon: The pilot balloon is connected to the cuff and serves as an indicator of cuff inflation. It allows the clinician to monitor and adjust the cuff pressure but does not have a role in maintaining ventilation during tube obstruction.

 

Option D. Radiopaque line: The radiopaque line is a feature embedded in the wall of the endotracheal tube, making it visible on X-rays. This line helps verify the correct placement of the tube within the airway but does not assist in ventilation or safety during obstructions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Murphy’s eye is a safety feature found on endotracheal tubes that provides an alternative route for ventilation if the main lumen becomes obstructed, ensuring continuous airflow and reducing the risk of mucosal trauma. Understanding this feature is essential for airway management and maintaining effective ventilation during anesthesia and critical care.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

 

Elective surgery deferral based on respiratory disease severity and COVID-19 recovery:

 

  • 4 weeks: For an asymptomatic patient with mild respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who did not need hospital treatment.
  • 8 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who was hospitalized in the ward.
  • 12 weeks: For a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit due to respiratory infection.

 

Application:

 

  • As this patient was symptomatic but did not need hospitalization, elective surgery can be deferred for 6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 weeks: This timeline is recommended for symptomatic patients who were hospitalized in the ward, which does not apply to this patient.

 

Option C. 12 weeks: This timeline is for patients who were admitted to the intensive care unit due to a respiratory infection, which also does not apply to this patient.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeline is for asymptomatic patients with mild respiratory symptoms, which is not the case for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 849

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?

 

  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation

 

EtCO2-End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 only

 

Explanation:

 

1. CO2 embolism: During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Severe bronchospasm: Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.

 

3. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.

 

4. Single bronchus intubation: If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucormycosis

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis.

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (Mucor, Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect BDG (in ng/ml) by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes.

 

Level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose candidiasis as Candida species produce BDG.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: The assay is also effective for diagnosing aspergillosis since Aspergillus species produce BDG.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis pneumonia: Pneumocystis jirovecii, the causative agent of Pneumocystis pneumonia, produces BDG, making the assay useful for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay is not effective for diagnosing mucormycosis because the fungi causing mucormycosis (Mucor, Rhizopus) either lack (1-3)-β-D-glucan or produce it at minimal levels. This assay is useful for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis pneumonia which involve fungi that produce significant levels of BDG.

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

 

Components of High-Quality CPR:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Effective CPR includes the following components:

 

  • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2529-2534

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

 

  • The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • The patient is also hemodynamically unstable, as indicated by the low blood pressure (70/40 mm Hg) and feeble pulse.
  • When a patient presents with SVT and hemodynamic instability, immediate rhythm conversion is essential.
  • The recommended treatment in such cases is direct current (DC) cardioversion.
  • This involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore a normal rhythm and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV adenosine: Adenosine temporarily slows or stops the heart's electrical activity and is often the first-line treatment for terminating stable, narrow complex supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, its short-lived effects make it less suitable.

 

Option B. IV diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the rate in atrial fibrillation or flutter and certain types of SVT. In hemodynamically unstable patients, slowing the heart rate without converting the rhythm can be dangerous.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is an antiarrhythmic drug used to treat certain types of atrial fibrillation or flutter. It's not the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable SVT and carries a risk of proarrhythmia, meaning it can sometimes cause new or worsening rhythm problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1744

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

 

Explanation

 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):

 

MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:

 

  1. Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  2. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  3. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  4. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.

 

Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:

 

  • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.

 

Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.

 

Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disability limitation

 

  • The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection.
  • Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

 

Option C. Primary prevention: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Health promotion: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

questions.text: Match the following:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

The correct matching of the diseases with their diagnostic techniques is as follows:

 

  1. Leprosy - d. Split skin smear
  2. Tinea capitis - c. KOH wet mount
  3. Contact dermatitis - b. Patch test
  4. Lupus vulgaris - a. Biopsy

 

Other options:

 

The other options provided in the multiple choice (A, B, and C) are incorrect matchings of the diseases and diagnostic techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each skin condition has a specific diagnostic test:

 

  • Leprosy is diagnosed using a split skin smear, typically from the earlobe.
  • Tinea capitis, a fungal infection, is diagnosed using a KOH wet mount of skin, nail, or hair scrapings.
  • Contact dermatitis is evaluated using a patch test to identify allergens.
  • Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is diagnosed through a skin biopsy to look for granulomas.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

choices.text: They increase the release of endorphins to block pain signals.
They inhibit calcium channels in sensory neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release.
They block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization.
They enhance potassium efflux from neurons, hyperpolarizing the nerve membrane.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic for the removal of a small skin lesion on her forearm. The procedure is planned under local anesthesia using lidocaine. Before administering the anesthetic, the patient expresses curiosity about how the medication will prevent her from feeling pain. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) They block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization.

 

Explanation:

 

Local anesthetics, such as lidocaine, work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels on the nerve membrane, which prevents the influx of sodium ions necessary for the depolarization of the nerve. This inhibition of sodium entry stops the propagation of action potentials along the nerve, effectively blocking the transmission of pain signals to the brain. The anesthetics have the highest affinity for sodium channels in their inactivated state, which occurs after the channels have been opened and before they return to their resting state. By stabilizing the nerve membrane and preventing conduction, local anesthetics provide effective pain relief during procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) They increase the release of endorphins to block pain signals: Endorphins are natural painkillers released by the body, but local anesthetics do not function by modulating endorphin release. Their primary action is at the sodium channel level within nerve cells.

 

Option B) They inhibit calcium channels in sensory neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release: This mechanism is associated with certain drugs like calcium channel blockers, not local anesthetics. Local anesthetics specifically target sodium channels, not calcium channels.

 

Option D) They enhance potassium efflux from neurons, hyperpolarizing the nerve membrane: Potassium channel modulation is not the primary mechanism of local anesthetics. While potassium movement does affect nerve activity, local anesthetics specifically act by blocking sodium channels to prevent depolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local anesthetics block sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing depolarization and action potential propagation, which results in the inhibition of pain sensation during medical procedures. Understanding this mechanism is crucial for appreciating how these drugs achieve their anesthetic effects.

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.text: A pediatrician at a district hospital encounters an 18-month-old boy from a remote village with breathing difficulties, cough, cold, and fever for the past few days. The child is active, with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute and no chest retractions. How should the pediatrician advise the parents? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

 

  • Based on the provided clinical information, it is evident that the child is suffering from pneumonia.
  • The recommended treatment for pneumonia in children aged 2 months to 5 years involves administering oral amoxicillin along with home care.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma 

 

The presence of a translocation t(8;14) is characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma. The same is confirmed by the tumor cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli.

 

Direct lines from Robbins.. - ”When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: Characterized by t(14;18) translocation and involves BCL2 gene, not typically presenting with jaw swelling.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Does not involve t(8;14) translocation and has different histopathological features.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Plasma cell neoplasm, typically presents with bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia, not with t(8;14) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known allergy to penicillin presents with a enterococcal endocarditis. The physician needs to prescribe an antibiotic but wants to ensure it is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy. The patient has had previous allergic reactions to penicillin, including rash and swelling. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in a patient allergic to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • The clinical scenario involves a 45-year-old patient with enterococcal endocarditis and a known allergy to penicillin, presenting with previous allergic reactions including rash and swelling. 
  • The physician needs to choose an antibiotic that is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy as well as effective for enterococcal endocarditis. Let's review the options:
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is not related to penicillin. 
  • It is safe for patients with penicillin allergies and is commonly used to treat gram-positive infections, including those caused by enterococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is generally considered safe for patients with penicillin allergies because it does not share the beta-lactam ring structure of penicillins, which is typically responsible for allergic reactions. However, aztreonam is effective only against gram negative bacteria and is not suitable for enterococcal infections which is a gram positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin. Although cephalosporins have a beta-lactam ring similar to penicillins, the rate of cross-reactivity is relatively low, especially with third-generation cephalosporins. However, caution is advised in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a penicillin derivative and should be avoided in patients with penicillin allergies due to the high risk of cross-reactivity and potential for severe allergic reactions.

 

Conclusion

 

The safest options for a patient with a penicillin allergy are:

 

Aztreonam (Option a)

 

Vancomycin (Option b)

 

Given the specific need to avoid penicillin and its derivatives and to treat gram positive (enterococcal) infections, Vancomycin is a safe and effective choice for treating enterococcal endocarditis in this patient. Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

b. Vancomycin

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion are characteristic of mucormycosis, a serious fungal infection commonly seen in diabetic patients and other immunocompromised individuals. Amphotericin B is the preferred initial treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad antifungal coverage and effectiveness against Mucorales, the group of fungi responsible for this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily for Candida and Cryptococcus infections. It is not effective against Mucorales and therefore not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is another antifungal agent with a broad spectrum of action but has limited use due to its side effects and is not effective against Mucorales, making it inappropriate for mucormycosis treatment.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea infections) and is not effective against Mucorales. It is not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

 

Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): pair of tracts that interconnect CN VI and CN III nuclei. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is responsible for coordinating horizontal eye movements. The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and travels to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). From there, an output goes to the left VI nerve nucleus, which supplies the left lateral rectus muscle, causing abduction. Another output from the left PPRF goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing the right eye to adduct.

 

If there is a lesion in the right MLF, it leads to the failure of adduction of the right eye. However, the left eye abducts normally. This is the classic presentation of INO.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th Nerve nucleus: A lesion here would result in an inability to abduct the eye on the same side, not INO.

 

Option C. Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF): A lesion here would typically affect both the initiation of gaze to the ipsilateral side and horizontal gaze coordination, leading to symptoms different from typical INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: Identify the lesion as shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropathic ulcer

 

  • The provided image indicates the presence of a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Neuropathic ulcers, also known as trophic ulcers, are the result of nerve damage, typically in individuals with conditions like diabetes or peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are often painless and can develop on the soles of the feet or other areas subject to pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial insufficiency: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically caused by poor blood circulation, often due to arterial disease. They often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and can appear as painful, pale wounds with well-defined edges. Other signs of ischemia are seen

 

 

Option C. Venous ulcers: Venous ulcers are typically caused by venous insufficiency, which leads to poor blood circulation in the legs. These ulcers often appear near the ankles and are characterized by swelling, redness, and sometimes pain.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous ulcers: Tuberculous ulcers are a manifestation of tuberculosis infection in the skin. They are characterized by the presence of nodules or ulcers with undermined edges and a necrotic center.

 

 

Tuberculous ulcer with typical bluish undermined margins overlying sternal tuberculosis focus  

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuropathic ulcers result from peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation over pressure points leads to unnoticed minor wounds or cuts, eventually developing into ulcers.
  • Features of neuropathic ulcers include painless, punched out ulcers with regular margins, commonly located on the plantar surface of the foot.
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

 

The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst, with the characteristic black punctum.

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • The most common locations for sebaceous cysts are the face, neck, chest, and back especially postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.
  • They typically appear as small, painless lumps that are round or oval in shape.
  • Treatment for sebaceous cysts involves surgical removal of the cyst. This is usually done under local anesthesia, and involves making a small elliptical incision in the skin and removing the cyst and its contents.
  • It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign, slow-growing cystic lesion that can occur in various parts of the body, including the head and neck.
  • These cysts are often present from birth (congenital) and can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and sometimes sebaceous (oil-producing) material.
  • Dermoid cysts are typically painless unless they become infected or inflamed.
  • Treatment involves surgical removal to prevent complications or for cosmetic reasons.

 

Option C. Meningioma:

 

  • A meningioma is a typically benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing and may not cause symptoms initially.
  • When symptoms occur, they can include headaches, seizures, changes in vision or hearing, and neurological deficits.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging studies like MRI and CT scans, and treatment may involve surgery or radiation therapy depending on the tumor's location and size.

 

Option D. Postauricular Fistula:

 

  • A postauricular fistula, also known as a auricular sinus or pit, is a small hole or pit located in front of or behind the ear.
  • It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present from birth.
  • These pits can sometimes become infected, leading to symptoms like pain, swelling, and discharge.
  • Surgical removal may be considered if there are recurrent infections or other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
