questions.text: The half-life of letrozole is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 48 hours

 

  • The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours.
  • Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor which is used in the treatment of ER +ve breast cancers in post-menopausal women.
  • It is also the DOC for treating infertility due to anovulation in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours. It is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of ER+ breast cancer in post-menopausal women and as the drug of choice for treating infertility due to anovulation in women with PCOS.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Amniotic fluid index determination

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the labor room? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a procedure called Cardiotocography (CTG). CTG is a method used to monitor the fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. It helps assess the well-being of the fetus and identify any signs of fetal distress.

 

Key points about Cardiotocography (CTG):

 

  • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST).
  • During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure in which a sample of amniotic fluid is aspirated for prenatal diagnosis or therapeutic purposes. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. MCA Doppler: MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler is performed to assess fetal growth restriction and fetal anemia. It is an ultrasound procedure and does not match the image shown.

 

Option D. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI): AFI is an ultrasound estimation of amniotic fluid volume. It is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiotocography (CTG) is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. When performed antenatally without labor, it is referred to as a Non-Stress Test (NST).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg339, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg122

questions.text: Match the following cell types and the malignancy they are associated with: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c  

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Type A-delta fibers
Type B fibers
Type A-alpha fibers

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department with severe lacerations on his hand after an accident at work. The attending physician decides to perform a minor surgical procedure under local anesthesia. Despite administering the anesthetic, the patient continues to report a lingering dull ache and burning sensation, although sharper, immediate pain is reduced. The physician explains that different types of nerve fibers respond variably to anesthetics, and some are more resistant than others. Which type of nerve fiber is most likely least susceptible to the effects of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Type C fibers

 

Explanation:

 

Type C fibers are the least susceptible to local anesthetics due to their unmyelinated and small diameter characteristics. Local anesthetics exert their effects by blocking sodium channels, which inhibits the initiation and propagation of action potentials along nerves. Because C fibers lack myelination, they present a barrier to the anesthetic’s effectiveness, requiring higher concentrations for adequate blockade. These fibers are responsible for transmitting dull, diffuse pain and autonomic signals. The sequence of nerve fiber susceptibility to local anesthetics is B > A-delta > A-gamma > A-beta > A-alpha > C, indicating that C fibers are the most resistant. B fibers, which are highly myelinated, are the most easily blocked, whereas C fibers, being unmyelinated, stand as the least affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A-delta fibers: These fibers are thinly myelinated and transmit sharp, localized pain. Due to their myelination, A-delta fibers are more susceptible to local anesthetics than C fibers. Their small size and presence of myelin make them relatively easier targets for anesthetic action, although not as easily blocked as B fibers.

 

Option B. Type B fibers: B fibers are small, myelinated fibers involved in autonomic functions. They are the most susceptible to local anesthetics and are typically blocked first due to their thin myelination, allowing easy access for the anesthetic agents. Their susceptibility is the highest among nerve fibers.

 

Option C. Type A-alpha fibers: A-alpha fibers are large, heavily myelinated fibers that control motor functions and proprioception. Although these fibers are relatively resistant compared to other A fibers, they are still more easily blocked than C fibers. Their substantial diameter requires higher anesthetic doses, but they are not as resistant as C fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type C fibers are the most resistant to local anesthetics due to their small, unmyelinated structure, requiring higher anesthetic concentrations for effective blockade. The order of nerve fiber susceptibility is B > A-delta > A-gamma > A-beta > A-alpha > C, with B fibers being the most susceptible and C fibers the least. This hierarchy is crucial in understanding why some sensations persist despite anesthetic administration.

choices.text: β-2 microglobulin
Calcium levels
Serum creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole.

 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include:
    1. Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge: The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
    2. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5: This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
    3. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test): The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
    4. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuko-reduced RBCs

 

The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leuko-reduced RBCs

 

Fever (elevation of temperature by 1º C or 2º F) , chills, or rigors resulting from cytokines released by leukocyte in transfused red cell or platelet components is called as non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reaction. It is a diagnosis of exclusion, as hemolytic and septic reactions can present similarly.

 

Prevention –

 

  1. Pre-storage leukoreduction
  2. Acetaminophen if persistent fever
  3. Routine pretreatment with acetaminophen
  4. Use of platelet additive solution
  5. Plasma reduced or washed products if severe reactions
  6. Restrictive transfusion approach in high-risk patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are not used to prevent transfusion reactions. They are used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing FNHTR, which is not caused by bacterial contamination.

 

Option C. Irradiation: Irradiation of blood products is used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GvHD), a different type of transfusion reaction, but it does not prevent FNHTR.

 

Option D. Washed RBCs: Washing RBCs removes plasma proteins and is used to prevent allergic reactions in patients with a history of severe allergic transfusion reactions, but it is not specifically aimed at preventing FNHTR. However, washed products can be used if the FNHTR is severe or recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leuko-reduced RBCs are the preferred method to reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), especially in patients requiring frequent transfusions like those with thalassemia.

 

  • FNHTRs are commonly due to cytokines released from donor leukocytes or recipient antibodies against donor leukocytes.
  • Leukoreduction removes most white blood cells from the blood product, thereby:
    • Reducing cytokine accumulation
    • Lowering risk of FNHTRs
    • Also helps prevent HLA alloimmunization and CMV transmission

questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Levopropoxyphene

 

  • Propoxyphene has two isomers: Levopropoxyphene and Dextropropoxyphene. Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive. It is an opioid derivative that acts centrally as a strong and partial µ receptor agonist and helps to reduce the cough reflex. It has no analgesic property but can cause some degree of sedation. Please note that the other isomer dextropropoxyphene is mainly used as an analgesic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ambroxol is derived from bromhexine. It increases mucociliary clearance, thereby providing relief in productive cough. Thus it is primarily used as a mucolytic (not anti-tussive). Further it is not an opioid.

 

Option B. Diphenoxylate or Loperamide is indicated for non-infective diarrhea. These are not used as anti-tussive.

 

Option D. Levorphanol is a synthetic opioid which is chiefly used in the management of moderate to severe pain. It also have some anti-tussive properties similar to codeine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid specifically used for its antitussive properties. While levorphanol is also an opioid with antitussive effects, it is more commonly used for pain relief. Levopropoxyphene's primary indication as an antitussive makes it the most appropriate choice among the given options.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Divalent metal transporter 1

 

DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

 

Luminal nonheme iron is mostly in the Fe [3] + (ferric state and is reduced to Fe [2] + (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases, such as b cytochromes and STEAP3. Fe [2] + iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

Fe [2] + iron destined for the circulation, is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin. This process is coupled to the oxidation of Fe [2] + iron to Fe [3] + iron, which is carried out by the iron oxidases hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin: Ferroportin is not involved in the initial transport of iron into the enterocyte. Instead, it is responsible for exporting iron from the enterocyte into the bloodstream. Ferroportin also works in tandem with hephaestin to ensure that Fe²⁺ iron is oxidized to Fe³⁺ before being released into circulation.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 2: There is no known transporter named "Divalent metal transporter 2" involved in iron absorption or transport within enterocytes. This option is incorrect and may be a distractor or incorrect reference.

 

Option D. Haptocorrin: Haptocorrin is a protein that binds vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in the stomach, protecting it from degradation. It is not involved in iron transport or metabolism, making this option incorrect in the context of iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the transport of Fe²⁺ iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes, facilitating iron absorption in the gut.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1230

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: A female patient has been receiving first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder for 6 months. She is fasting for religious reasons and is experiencing seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness. Which of the following tests should be performed to help diagnose her condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum lithium level

 

The patient's symptoms of seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness are highly suggestive of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index, with toxicity often occurring at levels above 1.5 mEq/L. Fasting and dehydration can exacerbate lithium toxicity due to increased renal absorption of lithium, which occurs similarly to sodium under these conditions.

 

Given that the patient has been on first-line pharmacological treatment for bipolar disorder and her symptoms align with those of lithium toxicity, checking serum lithium levels is the most appropriate diagnostic step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum potassium level: While potassium imbalances can cause muscle weakness and arrhythmias, these are less likely to be the primary issue given the patient's history of bipolar treatment and her current symptoms. Potassium levels do not directly explain the symptoms related to lithium toxicity.

 

Option C. ECG: An ECG might be useful in some scenarios to identify heart issues, but it is less likely to provide insights into the patient's symptoms related to bipolar treatment and fasting. It is not the first-line diagnostic test for suspected lithium toxicity.

 

Option D. Serum sodium level: While fasting might affect sodium levels, the kidneys typically compensate to maintain serum sodium levels. However, this compensation also increases lithium reabsorption, leading to toxicity. Measuring serum sodium levels alone is unlikely to provide a definitive diagnosis related to her symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum lithium level should be checked in a patient receiving lithium therapy for bipolar disorder who presents with symptoms such as seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and limb weakness, especially in the context of fasting or dehydration. This is crucial to diagnosing and managing lithium toxicity.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, doctor's signature is not needed.

 

the signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery?

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery
  5. 6th arch - Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. v

 

Explanation

 

All the given pairs of pharyngeal arteries and their arteries are correctly matched except for 'v' (option C).

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch has its blood supply on the left side from the left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus, not from the aorta.

 

Other options

 

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery: Correct. The maxillary artery is indeed a derivative of the first pharyngeal arch.
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery: Correct. The hyoid artery (or the stapedial artery in its embryonic context) is derived from the second pharyngeal arch.
  3. 3rd arch - Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery: Correct. The third pharyngeal arch gives rise to portions of the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery.
  4. 4th arch - Subclavian artery: Correct on the right side. The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the development of the right subclavian artery and part of the aortic arch on the left side.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Unpaired t test

 

When comparing the means of two independent groups, where one group serves as a control, the appropriate statistical test to use is the unpaired t-test. This test is designed to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of the two independent groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for categorical data to assess whether there is a significant association between two variables.

 

Option B. Z test: The Z test is typically used for large sample sizes to compare the means of two populations or to test proportions.

 

Option D. Paired T test: The paired t-test is used when comparing means from the same group at different times or under different conditions (e.g., before and after treatment).

 

Educational Objective:
